Document ID: 352-A Submission through Regulations.gov from Zander Huston 12-13-2024
Comment:
We write in response to the request for public comment on the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) draft Hazard Review: Wildland Fire Smoke Exposure Among Farmworkers and Other Outdoor Workers (CDC-2024-0065; NIOSH-352-A). We study the impacts of environmental health hazards and threats based on focus group research conducted with farmworkers in Oregon’s Willamette Valley. Questions one, five, six, and seven, to which NIOSH requested responses, are most relevant to our expertise and inform our public comment. Given our research focus, the present response will address farmworkers, but may also apply to other relevant populations.

We are pleased with NIOSH’s inclusion of a health equity analysis in section 2.4. The draft hazard review correctly identifies specific barriers farmworkers encounter, including social hierarchies’ harmful effects on health outcomes. The interactions between documentation status, exclusion from regulatory purview (e.g. exemption for agricultural workers in labor law), exclusion from social services based on documentation status or language access, workplace power dynamics related to socially constructed hierarchies, undercounting/under-researching vulnerable populations, subcontracting, language/literacy differences, the piece-rate system, and the other aspects of farmworkers’ social conditions that are described in the draft hazard review are essential to understand who is affected by smoke exposure and why. 

This characterization of farmworkers’ exposure could be improved by discussing the economic factors that influence their exposure to wildland fire smoke. The hazard review already mentions, in passing, healthcare access is limited by circumstances of poverty and ineligibility for subsidies. Low wages and other factors that cause economic precarity profoundly increase exposure and the burden of environmental hazards. Agricultural workers we interviewed describe routinely working in 115-degree weather with thick smoke during harvest season. For example, a participant described how “yo sentía en mis ojos que me caía como arenita, como no sé, tierra, o sea, todo el humo que estaba. Entonces es muy, muy peligroso salir también cuando está así” [I would feel all the smoke in my eyes that was falling on me like bits of sand or, I don’t know, dirt. So, it is very, very dangerous to go out when it is like this]. Farmworkers are aware that working in such conditions is dangerous to their health. Yet, many risk exposure, even acute and long-term health risks at the workplace, to secure groceries and rent. Another participant noted, “if there isn’t work…there isn’t [money] for the rent. And that is the main thing – the rent… because if you don’t pay, they kick you out.”  These competing priorities — safety and income — are essential to understanding and ameliorating farmworkers’ exposure to smoke. Meaningfully addressing the barriers farmworkers face in mitigating the risks of wildfire smoke exposure requires analysing and addressing the economic barriers workers face to reduce smoke exposure.

One of the research priorities correctly identified in section 6.4 relates to the barriers to implementing health and safety programs that protect farmworkers. Some research, including findings from the Michigan Farm Worker Project, has begun to address this question, emphasizing the role that workplace power dynamics and financial pressures play in inhibiting workplace safety.1  One study already cited in the draft hazard review found, using focus group interviews with farm workers, that themes such as “killing yourself to make a living” and “economic vulnerability” are important to understanding farmworkers’ health concerns.2 Disparate incentives between employer and employees and weak government enforcement often lead to businesses violating migrant workers’ safety protections.3 When this occurs, workers have to decide whether or how to balance their competing priorities. Poverty wages pressure farmworkers’ decision-making process when determining to continue working in hazardous environments.

2 Michael Flynn, Donald Eggerth, and C Jeffrey Jacobson Jr, “Undocumented status as a social determinant of occupational safety and health: The workers' perspective,” American Journal of Industrial Medicine 58, no. 11 (2015): 1127–1137.
3 Amy K. Liebman, Melinda F. Wiggins, Clermont Fraser, Jeffrey Levin, Jill Sidebottom, and Thomas A. Arcury, “Occupational Health Policy and Immigrant Workers in the Agriculture, Forestry, and Fishing Sector,” American Journal of Industrial Medicine 56, no. 8 (April 18, 2013): 975-984, https://doi.org/10.1002/ajim.22190; Sarah Bronwen Horton, They Leave Their Kidneys in the Fields: Illness, Injury, and Illegality among U.S. Farmworkers, (Oakland, CA: University of California Press, 2017); Carl Wilmsen, Diane Bush, and Dinorah Barton-Antonio, “Working in the Shadows: Safety and Health in Forestry Services in Southern Oregon,” Journal of Forestry 113, no. 3 (May 12, 2015): 315–24, https://doi.org/10.5849/jof.13-076; Lisbeth Iglesias-Rios, Alexa Kort, and Alexis J.
Handal, “Precarious Work and Housing for Michigan Farmworkers During the COVID-19 Pandemic and Beyond,” Journal of Agromedicine 29, no. 3, 432-450, DOI: 10.1080/1059924X.2024.2341803.

Recommendations presented in the draft hazard review rely on employers committing to adoption (in the context of both legally mandated – like Oregon – and voluntary measures) of measures like work relocation, worker rotation, length/intensity reduction shifts, work-rest cycles, and providing information in accessible languages and formats (which is especially important for the indigenous farmworker populations who speak a variety of languages4). In addition to these strategies, it should be added that employers modify the pay system (the perverse incentive of the piece-rate compensation is already outlined in section 2.4.4) and the wage scale to encourage safe decisions from farmworkers under the administrative controls paradigm. 

Historically, inattentive employers to worker needs have been met with pressure from workers themselves, governmental agencies, labor groups, advocacy organizations, and other stakeholders.5 This is evidence that recommendations without rules and enforcement will be of limited relevance and protection to farmworker populations. For example, workers we interviewed indicated that even basic occupational requirements, such as hand washing stations and shaded areas, were not provided by employers. These are sanitary and safety conditions already legally mandated in Oregon. The draft recommendations note that the employer cannot feasibly make all changes immediately due to short harvest time frames, labor market conditions, and other factors. However, employees also have constraints around their family life, health concerns, and other personal and social needs. Flexibility for employers (often centered around maintaining production) is often a contradictory goal from employee flexibility (often related to family/social obligations, pace of work, and workplace safety).6 In this context, it would be worthwhile to make recommendations for when employer and employee interests diverge in the context of wildfire smoke exposure. It would be appropriate for NIOSH to mention the utility of government regulation and enforcement to promote safe workplace practices that reduce wildfire smoke exposure, even when it contradicts employers’ production goals.

4 Jennifer Martinez, Lynn Stephen, Ronald L Mize, Gabriela Pérez Báez, Valentin Sanchez, and Julie Samples, “COVID-19’s Disproportionate on Oregon Farmworkers is Far-Reaching and Long-Term,” Oregon COVID-19 Farmworker Study, July 14, 2021, 21-24, https://cirsinc.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/COFS_Report2021_ENG_FULL-compressed.pdf.
5 Dvera I. Saxton, The Devil's Fruit: Farmworkers, Health, and Environmental Justice (New Brunswick: Rutgers University Press, 2021); Mario Jimenez Sifuentez, Of Forests and Fields: Mexican Labor in the Pacific Northwest (New Brunswick: Rutgers University Press, 2016); Sarah Bronwen Horton, They Leave Their Kidneys in the Fields Illness, Injury, and Illegality among U.S. Farmworkers (Oakland: University of California Press, 2016); Jamie Goldberg, “Two Oregon businesses whose workers died during heat wave fight state fines,” OregonLive/Oregonian, May 6, 2022, https://www.oregonlive.com/business/2022/05/two-oregon-businesses-whose-workers-died-during-heat-wave-fightstate-fines.html.

Farmworkers we have interviewed care deeply about minimizing health risks in the workplace when they are in control. Often, they are forced to make the best out of exploitative and abusive conditions and are pressured to engage in unsafe work practices and refrain from reporting health concerns (including through threat of firing or deportation).7 As written currently, the draft hazard does not adequately account for the common and powerful barriers to implementing the recommendations. Additional recommendations could be added to the hazard review to target alternative actors. Possibilities include:


1. Broadening many of the recommendations in section 5.2.2.1 and elsewhere beyond being addressed to employers. The relevant actors should be expanded to include worker organizations, government, advocacy organizations, and other groups who may influence workplace safety practices. This should include recommendations that appropriate actions like employer provision of PPE and inclement weather leave be codified into law and enforced.
2. Augmenting section 5.1.2.3 to recommend employers and social service providers promote increased access to sufficient air conditioning, showers, insulation, air filtration, and washing and drying machines (the importance of which are already described in section 2.4.5).8
3. Adding more details to section 5.2.2.3, emphasizing to healthcare professionals that some populations may have additional barriers to accessing medical services (described in the health equity section9), requiring special efforts to best provide care to farm workers. Our research indicates that farmworkers may perceive medical professionals negatively because their health concerns are dismissed. Additionally, it should be noted that farmworkers' health concerns related to repetitive labor and exposures to hazardous pollutants are often mischaracterized as stress.
4. Recommending actions that positively influence workers’ decision-making matrix toward avoiding unnecessary smoke exposure by reducing poverty, increasing the availability of social services, and reducing power imbalances between employers and employees. For example, farm worker climate change funds – similar to what was temporarily established in Oregon’s Senate Bill 556110 – could provide financial relief to vulnerable populations at high risk of exposure to wildfire smoke. Additionally, recommendations could be made for increased wages and overtime pay.
To summarize, we recommend that 1) the economic factors influencing farmworker exposure to wildfire smoke be more fully incorporated into Chapter 2 and 2) the health equity analysis be integrated into the recommendations by better addressing relevant actors who are not employers. • Justification: My research identified significant gaps in understanding chemical hazards present in wildfire smoke, particularly among non-leadership personnel. • Justification: My dissertation highlighted barriers to effective RPE use, including fit issues, discomfort, and lack of access during critical times. Research into the effects of occupational exposure to wildfire smoke outside of the wildfire firefighter population remains limited, and even data-based estimates of potential workers exposed has significant limitations, due to the patterns of seasonal work, precarious or temporary employment and inherent worker vulnerability present within many of the worker groups with significant outdoor work duties, particularly the agricultural worker population.

Postal and delivery workers often lack air conditioning and have frequent stops, leading them to keep open doors regardless of smoke (National Association of Letter Carriers, 2023). Estimating the number of potential workers faces challenges due to the increasing use of independent contractors or “gig workers”. These workers in particular face significant challenges to advocate for improved workplace safety, and also have financial incentives to minimize delays in their route. This may contribute to higher levels of ambient air pollution exposure, and increased negative health consequences.

Similarly, while not the specific target of this proposal, even workers characterized as “indoor workers” may face significant exposure to wildfire smoke in the workplace. A study of childcare facilities across British Columbia identified significantly higher indoor PM2.5 concentrations during wildfire events (Lee et al. Environmental Health Research 2024, PMID 34574730). For facilities such as packing or processing plants where outside doors are typically left open to provide ventilation and reduce heat, these exposures may be significantly higher.

Comment:
The NIOSH Draft Hazard Review: Wildland Fire Smoke Exposure Among Farmworkers and Other Outdoor Workers provides much needed insight into the health hazard exposures in non-firefighter occupational settings. The NIOSH work to analyze relevant research and apply the research to develop a process for managing worker exposure is commendable. Document ID: 352-A Submission through Regulations.gov from Les Boord 1-8-2025.pdf
Comment:
Comment # 1:
As described by the EPA, the size of particles affects the potential to cause health effects. PM2.5 is considered to be the greatest risk for worker exposure. PM2.5 designates particles less than 2.5 micrometers in diameter. Particles from smoke tend to be very small, with a size range near the wavelength of visible light (0.4–0.7 micrometers).
Given the range of the wildland smoke particle size, it may be beneficial to include a discussion about the particulate filtration efficiency of NIOSH approved particulate respirators. Specifically, NIOSH tests filtration efficiency at a most penetrating particle size (MPPS). Particle size variants larger and smaller than the tested MPPS are captured at a greater efficiency.
Previous NIOSH NPPTL research and presentations explain particulate capture technology even extending to nano size particles.
(Reference: EPA [2019c]. Wildfire smoke: a guide for public health officials. Washington, DC: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, https://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyPDF.cgi/P10135FE.PDF?Dockey=P10135FE.PDF )

Document ID: 352-A Submission through Regulations.gov from Les Boord 1-8-2025.pdf
Comment:
Comment #2:
The document discussions addressing respiratory protection are both trite and pithy. Readers of the document will likely believe that a NIOSH approved N95 filtering facepiece respirator (FFR) is the NIOSH preferred respirator used for inhalation protection from PM2.5 wildland fire smoke. While the N95 FFR can be used for protection, there are other particulate respirator configurations that provide the needed inhalation protection.
Appropriate respiratory protection technology for the PM2.5 wildland fire smoke hazard is a NIOSH approved particulate respirator selected using the OSHA Assigned Protection Factor (APF) to achieve a NIOSH ECC 2 level of inhalation hazard. Particulate filtration can be any NIOSH approved efficiency with an N, R or P series rating. The respirator can be a filtering facepiece respirator, an elastomeric ¼ mask, elastomeric ½ mask, full facepiece, hood or a powered air purifying respirator (PAPR).
While the appropriate technical description for respiratory protection may seem to be overly complex, recent experience with supply shortages of N95 FFRs due to COVID justifies the need to utilize the full range of NIOSH approved respirators that meet the protective needs of PM2.5 exposure.
The OSHA APF table includes the entire range of face coverings (1/4, 1/2, full, hood and PAPR) and NIOSH approvals exist for a range of filtration efficiencies at N, R, and P series rating.

Document ID: 352-A Submission through Regulations.gov from Les Boord 1-8-2025.pdf
Comment:
Comment #3:
The document clearly states only inhalation hazards are addressed. However, some information addressing other routes of exposure would be worthwhile to consider. Dermal and ocular exposures do occur and can be problematic even though they do not have the potential to transmit into the blood stream as with inhalation hazards.
In particular, work in a wildland fire smoke workplace potentially exposes the ocular surface directly to PM2.5 which can lead to ocular diseases. (Reference: Consequences of exposure to particulate matter on the ocular surface: Mechanistic insights from cellular mechanisms to epidemiological findings, https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/38311159/ ).
Additional information on potential ocular diseases resulting from exposure is discussed in the following publication:
Impact on Eye Health Regarding Gaseous and Particulate Pollutants, https://aaqr.org/articles/aaqr-20-03-fc-0098.
While sufficient information on ocular exposure may not exist to categorize exposure levels to fit the NIOSH ECC levels, it may be worthwhile to recommend the use of protective eyewear when working in any level of exposure.
Similarly, dermal exposure will occur when working in a wildland smoke environment. Again, it may be worthwhile to recommend that covering exposed skin areas with clothing can be helpful.
Since the ocular and dermal particulate exposure research may not be as robust as inhalation research, a limited discussion could be added as an appendix to the Hazard Review. Inclusion of dermal and ocular information would make the NIOSH Hazard Review: Wildland Fire Smoke Exposure Among Farmworkers and Other Outdoor Workers a complete wildland fire exposure resource for worker protection.

Document ID: 352-A Submission through Regulations.gov from Les Boord 1-8-2025.pdf
Comment:
Comment #4
NIOSH should consider including a discussion about respirator selection and, include a discussion that selection and use of a particulate respirator may not be appropriate to address all hazards associated with wildfire events. Although PM2.5 is considered to be the greatest wildfire event risk, other exposure hazards may be present. Workplace location relative to the wildfire source and the presence of other non-wildfire hazards may require protection. This consideration is especially important for non-first responder outdoor work such as assessing the event, clean-up, and other support activities. NIOSH has established guidance regarding respirator selection that can be used in these situations.

Farmworkers are at the forefront of climate-related emergencies: as outdoor workers, they are among the first to encounter extreme weather conditions, including heat and wildfire smoke. Comment:
Chapter 5, Question 5: What additional information should NIOSH consider to improve the strategies identified in Chapter 5 for controlling exposure to wildland fire smoke (e.g., engineering controls, work practices, personal protective equipment) to make them more effective and reduce barriers to implementation? What additional controls could be considered to protect outdoor workers from wildland fire smoke? Please provide scientific evidence to support your response as necessary.
1) Elimination strategy: Using wildland management to reduce the likelihood of wildfires. Guidelines for correct management.
• A comment about this strategy is about the challenge in how to develop this management. For the state and county level it may be optimal to generate federal guidelines and standards of how wildfires programs should be designed and evaluated, and even what elements should be considered for its correct functioning. For example, it is important to include in the wildfire management a logic of working across departments, in which natural resources administration, industrial compliance, emergency response, transport administration, and urban planning can be interconnected and have mutual and permanent feedback. This logic has been already applied at the National Interagency Fire Center with an on-the-ground firefight effort perspective. Nonetheless, it is favorable to have an interagency workgroup within the state government structures that address and prevent wildfire with a comprehensive approach. Moreover, land management should be applied in private facilities, especially considering that farm work involves extensive lands under the ownership of a private enterprise. The land management should be within the daily activities of the company and be considered in the performance assessment, internalized as a program, which state authorities should evaluate. Both private programs and state evaluations would require general guidelines to be correctly developed. A good precedent is the sustainable land management practices recommended by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), which has an ecosystemic approach and targets both the public and private sectors, providing best practices for the Integrated Land Management (ILM) including fire control and land cover after fire (M.J. Sanz et al, 2017).

Comment:
2) Engineering controls: Using enclosed building, temporary or permanent structures and vehicles with filtered air. Recommendations specifically for wildland fire exposure:
• It would be good to have general recommendations about the distribution of these facilities and devices per surface and quantity of workers in the companies. In addition, a recommendation on the spatial distribution of these elements should be provided according to the type of workflow each outdoor workplace has, accessibility, and predicted level of exposure. Despite existing recommendations for this topic (p.71,74, 237-240 of the report), the complexity of wildland fire exposure requires a special analysis, that includes the fact that workers are not only highly exposed at the workplace but may be highly exposed in their communities too due to take-home route and environmental exposure. These make for constant exposure especially considering that many outdoor workers live near their workplace. For example, many farmworkers live in employer-provided housing (Grzywacz, J. G. et al., 2010), which is generally in the proximity of the farms. Considering this cumulative effect, the engineering controls should be stricter, carefully checked by safety officers, and inspected by authorities with specific standards and recommendations.

• For the education and training of workers, it must be a challenge to include wildland fire smoke as a new hazard within the already existing training programs. This protocol should be a simple and practical tool that helps to identify when to strengthen this training according to seasonality of wildland fires and early warnings.

Chapter 5, Question 8: What are the potential barriers to the understandability of the recommendations in Chapter 5 for outdoor workers and employers? When developing supplementary educational materials to support the implementation of these recommendations, how can NIOSH best address those barriers?
In general, we suggest that NIOSH provide more specific logistical guidance to outdoor workers and employers on how best to follow the recommendations that the agency provides.
• Page 241 of the Hazard Review addresses the need to have communication methods appropriate for people with low literacy levels. However, the agency should offer concrete recommendations on how to best carry that recommendation out in practice. For instance, a study on healthcare communication from 2020 demonstrated that using visual aids was highly useful in health education materials for persons with low literacy levels (Mbanda et. al, 2020). NIOSH can recommend that employers provide visual learning materials on smoke exposure to workers.

Comment: Page 255 recommends that workers talk with their doctors if they have issues that would make them more likely to have health effects from smoke exposure. While this is a good idea in theory, many farmworkers lack meaningful access to healthcare, and do not have primary care doctors. In a study from 2022, researchers found that farmworkers had difficulties accessing healthcare (Soto et. al, 2022). We recommend taking measures to increase farmworker access to healthcare so as to make the agency’s recommendation feasible.

Comment:
Please see below for a summary of our comments and recommendations:
Chapter 2 – Sources, populations, exposures
General Comments:
Public health surveillance approaches are population-based and can help identify prevention and intervention strategies to help protect workers. NIOSH funds state-based occupational health surveillance in several states and surveillance was cited as a critical component of a comprehensive program to tackling climate-related hazards in a scoping study. [1] Only medical surveillance (rather than state-based public health surveillance) and data collection are addressed in this document. CSTE recommends inclusion of surveillance methods – epidemiologic hazard surveillance, which can assess who may be at risk of wildland fire smoke exposure, and health surveillance, which can assess potential health impacts. Refer to CSTE document on Occupational Health Surveillance for Tracking Climate Related Health Impacts on Workers: Heat, Wildfires, and Floods. [2]

Comment:
Q: How could the outdoor worker populations who may be exposed to wildland fire smoke be more completely characterized in Chapter 2? Please provide supporting references.
Section 2.2.1 – Definition and Characteristics and Section 2.2.2.2 – Criteria to Define Outdoor Occupations
Given several approaches and that other workers can intermittently be exposed to wildland fires, CSTE recommends that NIOSH clarify their definition of outdoor worker as persons working a significant amount of time outdoors as part of their routine work activities and include other examples of how outdoor workers are defined (as listed above).
NIOSH’s method to define outdoor occupations is one of many population-based approaches, and jurisdictions may use other approaches. During the COVID-19 pandemic, CSTE developed a matrix to assess the degree to which a person in a given non-healthcare occupation may work indoors and outdoors. The matrix was created using several questions from the Occupational Information Network (O*NET). It resulted in 117 Standard Occupation Codes (SOC) - job titles characterized as “often outdoors” to “primarily outdoors” representing 11% of the U.S. workforce (excluding healthcare).[3] Other outdoor definitions taken from O*NET use the inverse of the reported frequency of working in indoor environmentally-controlled settings. [4] Jurisdictions, such as New York City, have relied on the Occupational Requirements Survey for information about outdoor work and identified gig workers, independent contractors and day laborers as working outdoors. [5]

Document ID: 352-A Submission through Regulations.gov from Janet Hamilton - CSTE 1-9-2025
Comment: In 2023, the CSTE Occupational Health Subcommittee convened a workgroup of epidemiologists, researchers, and public health experts to address the risks to workers that are posed by ongoing and rapidly increasing changes to the earth’s climate. The purpose of the workshop was to extend NIOSH-funded surveillance capacity for climate-related disasters, such as wildfires. CSTE recommended assessing worker populations using the tools mentioned above. However, assumptions about risk must be explicit. Outdoor workers as defined by these approaches may not include workers who can be exposed to wildfires such as nursing assistants and aides evacuating people from assisted living facilities as O*NET and the Occupational Requirements Survey assume outdoor presence as part of usual work duties. [2]

Chapter 3 – Health effects
General Comments:
As mentioned above within Chapter 2 comments, public health surveillance is a population-based, public health strategy that can help protect workers and mitigate climate-related hazards. [1] CSTE recommends expanding the language in the rule to include surveillance methods – hazard surveillance, which can assess who may be at risk of wildland fire smoke exposure, and health surveillance which can assess potential health impacts. There is no single data source that can identify all work-related injuries and illnesses. Multiple data sources are often needed, and jurisdictions need to identify the data sources they can access to recognize work-related health risks. Common data sources include syndromic surveillance, death record data, emergency and hospital discharge data, and workers’ compensations claims. CSTE has compiled information on surveillance methods and data sources within the document Occupational Health Surveillance for Tracking Climate Related Health Impacts on Workers: Heat, Wildfires, and Floods. [2]

Q: How could this document better identify and characterize the health hazards of exposures to wildland fire smoke based on the available scientific literature in Chapter 3? Is there additional scientific information to be considered regarding the adverse health endpoints associated with exposure to wildland fire smoke? Please provide scientific references to support your response as necessary.
Limited data are available on worker populations, as noted by NIOSH. States, Tribes, locals, and territories are leveraging a variety of data sources for examining the impacts of wildland fires and workers or adult working populations. We recommend that NIOSH add these two papers as references (Fitzsimmons et al. and Cabral and Dillender) which focus on wildfire smoke exposures as described herein. For example, Fitzsimmons et al. explored the impacts of the Canadian Wildfires among Massachusetts adults (18-64 years) who sought care for respiratory-related issues in emergency departments (ED). [8] Albeit few excess ED visits, they found Hispanic/Latino residents experienced the largest increases compared to other race/ethnicities. While not part of the NIOSH focus, Cabral and Dillender examined risk of injury in relation to wildfire smoke in workers’ compensation claims and found costs can be mitigated. [4]

Comment:
Dear Dr. Howard,
The Hazard Evaluation System and Information Service (HESIS) in the California Department of Public Health (CDPH) submits the following comments regarding the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health’s (NIOSH) draft Hazard Review – Wildland Fire Smoke Exposure Among Farmworkers and Other Outdoor Workers (CDC- NIOSH Document Draft 08-23-2024). HESIS is a program that provides information to assist employers, workers, and others to prevent injury or illness from chemical hazards in the workplace and translates scientific information into practical language to provide “early warnings” to prevent work-related chronic disease.
California has experienced many of its worst wildfires in recent years due to increasingly drier, hotter climates and historic land management practices. Many workers are increasingly at risk of exposure to wildfire and wildland fire smoke exposure including those who are outdoor and others who work in locations where smoke may travel.
NIOSH requested input from various organizations on several key questions that are listed below, and we have organized our response to flow from these questions to that aim. In addition, we provide more general comments pertaining to specific chapters below chapter headers.

Comment:
Chapter 1 – Introduction
1.2 – Background on Wildland Fire Smoke
NIOSH states “A coordinated effort among the agencies and organizations listed above seeks to better characterize the health risks of wildland firefighters and implement strategies to protect their health and well-being [Navarro et al. 2022; Wildland Fire Mitigation and Management Commission 2023]. (Page 3, Lines 28-31)” NIOSH could clarify if this effort will result in another hazard review on wildland firefighters for example and summarize the information once again in the Chapter 6.

Comment:
Chapter 2 – Sources, populations, exposures
General Comments:
Surveillance was considered a key priority for addressing climate-related hazards by NIOSH. (Schulte, Bhattacharya et al. 2016) HESIS proposes the addition of a section within Chapter 2 featuring other approaches used to characterize workers or a surrogate population who may be exposed to wildland fire smoke whether outdoor or indoor as well as occupational hazard surveillance/tracking as a method to identify outdoor workers who may be exposed to wildland fire smoke. Few data are available about workers who may be exposed to wildland fire smoke and leveraging surveillance systems can offer insights – the following studies may be included. For example, Fitzsimmons et al. explored the impacts of the Canadian Wildfires among Massachusetts adults (18-64 years) who sought care for respiratory-related issues in emergency departments. (Fitzsimmons, Mahin et al. 2024) They found differences in the effects across race/ethnicity groups among adults of working age, with Hispanic/Latino residents experiencing the largest increase, albeit small in terms of excess visits. Although injury-focused and outside the current NIOSH review scope, Cabral and Dillender used measure outdoor and risk exposure derived by industry-occupation sets from workers’ compensation to assist with prioritizing higher risk from a severe injury. (Cabral and Dillender 2024) They found most smoke-induced injury increases resulted in costs that might be mitigated.

Document ID: 352-A Submission through Regulations.gov from Ximena Vergara - CDPH 11-12-2024
Comment:
Q: How could the outdoor worker populations who may be exposed to wildland fire smoke be more completely characterized in Chapter 2? Please provide supporting references.
2.2.1 - Definition and Characteristics of Outdoor Workers
HESIS proposes a modification of the term outdoor workers as persons working a significant amount of time outside a physical structure in rural, suburban, or urban areas as part of their routine work activities. Most of the characterization is about those occupations involving workers who must remain outside to finish their normal work activities and are consequently exposed to wildland fire smoke. This implies some assumptions about risk not explicitly stated e.g. the focus may be on either cumulative exposure to workers within an occupational title over a lifetime or intermittent exposures that happen as part of normal worker activities. Further, some other workers may also be exposed in the near field of a wildland fire for brief amounts of time. Nursing assistants or health aides may need to move patients during wildfires when assisted living and skilled nursing facilities need to be evacuated for example. This group of workers, also not emergency responders, would normally be considered indoor, but may be temporarily displaced from their worksite to outdoor environments and exposed to wildfire smoke.(Cabral and Dillender 2024, CSTE 2024) These intermittent exposures if occurring frequently enough may result in both acute and long-term health effects depending on the composition of the wildland fire burn mixture. Taken together, NIOSH has proposed an excellent approach to define outdoor workers; but the review requires more specificity about its outdoor worker definition and the assumptions about which workers are consider at risk.

Document ID: 352-A Submission through Regulations.gov from Ximena Vergara - CDPH 11-12-2024
Comment:
2.2.2.2 – Criteria to Define Outdoor Occupations
HESIS acknowledges NIOSH’s method to determine outdoor occupations as a sound approach for population-level assessment. However, other methods to determine outdoor workers may be included in the review. The Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologist (CSTE) Occupational Health Subcommittee developed a matrix to assess the degree which a person working within an occupation may be indoor and/or outdoor combined using several questions from Occupational Information Network (O*NET) resulting in 117 Standard Occupation Codes [(SOC) 2010 basis] titles considered at least often outdoors to primarily outdoors.(CSTE 2021) Other outdoor definitions taken from O*NET use the inverse of the reported frequency of working in indoor-environmentally controlled settings.(Cabral and Dillender 2024) In New York City, the Occupational Requirements Survey was used to identify outdoor workers and gig workers; independent contractors and day laborers were identified specifically using other approaches. (New York City Comptroller 2024) Lappe and Vargo assessed the impacts of wildfire smoke exposure on frontline workers in specific labor industries, including agriculture, fishing, mining, construction, manufacturing, warehousing, and transportation. (Lappe and Vargo 2022) Between two five-year time periods 2011-2015 and 2017-2021, they estimated an increase of 2,132 frontline worker-days of heavy smoke exposure for California workers with overall increase of 33,522,008 person-days in 2017-2021. They also noted large absolute increases for some states in the Midwest not typically considered to be affected by wildfires.

HESIS recommends that NIOSH expand their Table 2-4 with all the occupations determined as outdoor using their methodology. In reference to the list of 86.1% outdoor jobs by SOC major group (Page 68, Lines 34 – 39), employers, workers or other persons referencing this review may not necessarily understand or know which groups all these job titles fall within the SOC coding schema. Moreover, the methodology may not necessarily capture those in gig work, day laborers, window washers, dog walkers, or delivery drivers. To make clearer, we recommend displaying the entire list of detailed occupations.

3.1.1.3 Monographs of the International Agency for Research on Cancer
As there are key differences that can affect the level of exposure, we recommend discussion on differences between wildland firefighters and structural firefighters (Page 115, Lines 26-34). Most notably, wildland firefighters typically do not wear respiratory protection while structural firefighters wear Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA) when performing firefighting suppression activities. Extrapolating data from structural firefighters to wildland firefighters likely underestimates the exposure and health effects.

Comment:
3.2.3.2 - Considerations for the Scoping Review Approach
While we appreciate that NIOSH is involved in initiatives to address mental health issues among workers and that this hazard review is limited to physical effects (Page 147, Lines 23-27), we think a discussion on the mental health effects will strengthen the basis for the review. Typically, mental health is seen as a separate category from physical effects, but mental health effects play a great deal in worker productivity, lost time, presenteeism, and chronic health effects. NIOSH has led in acknowledging this through their Total Worker Health™ approaches. (Schill and Chosewood 2013) There is intersectionality of these issues. Research including “The mental health and wellbeing effects of wildfire smoke: a scoping review” (Eisenman and Galway 2022) and “Wildfire smoke and symptoms affecting mental health among adults in the U.S. state of Oregon” (Mirabelli, Vaidyanathan et al. 2022) highlight this area.

Chapter 4 – Exposure assessment
General Comments:
Above we mentioned the approach for population-based public health, we now propose a section on how employers might be able to conduct an exposure assessment if they only have employee job duty statements and Air Quality Index (AQI). For example, employers could list of which job titles and workers have some component of their jobs or specific tasks involving outdoor work. These occupations and associated tasks can be written into the plans in case of a wildland fire event.
Tying to the purpose outlined in Section 4.1, we recommend that NIOSH consider adding a section in Chapter 4 on vulnerability assessment of worksites or industrial complexes using quantitative methods. This area is relatively new, and while challenging, can offer some value at risk scenarios for emergency response planning for workers who are mainly in a fixed location. (Ricci, Misuri et al. 2024)

4.3 – Considerations for an Exposure Assessment
HESIS recommends simplifying the tiered approach (Tiers 1, 2, and 3) presented in this section which may prove difficult for many employers to understand and implement, particularly those without in-house industrial hygiene or safety expertise. NIOSH should consider reframing the section to highlight Tier 1 data sources as the most straightforward way for employers to assess risk and make decisions about control measures to protect employees based on predefined AQI thresholds. Tier 1 should be the primary focus, with Tiers 2 and 3 presented as supplementary options for specialized circumstances/end users. Specifically, there appears to be a focus on Tier 3 assessment strategies which are rarely used in typical workplaces. Most employers will need to engage with third-party contractors who possess the knowledge and resources to conduct detailed exposure assessments of wildfire smoke constituents; this is likely not needed in most cases.

Comment:
Child farmworkers
According to the National Agricultural Workers Survey (NAWS), 7% of workers are 14 to 19 years old and 18% are 55 or older.1 Children as young as 12 are able to legally work in agriculture; there are approximately 300,000 child farmworkers.2 Children are more vulnerable to adverse health effects from air pollution. This includes susceptibility to chronic diseases in their developing lungs. Recommended PPE such as N95 respirators to protect workers from wildfire smoke are not sized and tested accordingly for children and adolescents.3 There are no specific masks designed for and tested in children that are available to protect them from the common particulate air pollutants today.

Comment:
Fear of retaliation
Retaliation in agriculture is well-documented. Legal services providers and other community partners regularly share incidents of workers who were fired or blacklisted because they express concerns over working conditions. Most workers earn their wages using a piece-rate so their wages are directly tied to their productivity and efficiency. Workers are less likely to stop work, even during a wildfire, unless they are provided specific instruction by their employer. Any administrative controls, especially reductions of shifts, should be accompanied by other incentives to ensure that workers do not lose pay and are not discouraged from taking the necessary precautions to protect their health. Any standards must have strong retaliation protections so workers are empowered to assert their rights.

Control measures, including communication methods regarding wildfire smoke exposure and worker training, must be culturally and linguistically accessible for all workers in various languages and disseminated via communication channels most utilized by farmworkers.

Guidance for Co-Exposures: NIOSH asks whether “...the recommendations in Chapter 5 adequately address the protection of potentially disadvantaged or at-risk outdoor workers, such as persons with pre-existing health conditions (e.g., asthma, cardiovascular disease), migrant workers, persons of lower socioeconomic status, and elderly or minor workers? While we consider all outdoor workers to be at-risk from wildfire smoke, we recommend NIOSH strengthen the recommendations in the Hazard Review to better address the needs of disadvantaged or especially at-risk outdoor workers. In our changing climate, people are increasingly exposed to several hazards at the same time. This is especially true for outdoor workers, who are often exposed to compounding climate and weather extremes,19 in addition to workplace-specific exposures, and infectious disease. This increases the risk of poor outcomes in wildfire-smoke-exposed outdoor workers, consistent with their class-wide status as a “sensitive group”. We suggest NIOSH add to the recommendations in Chapter 5, including in the employee training section, information related to the heightened health risks of co-exposure, and how to protect outdoor workers who are exposed to multiple hazards including, but not limited to: wildfire smoke, heat, and infectious disease (including SARS-CoV-2, influenza, and Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza). Specific guidance for co-exposures is important, as the epidemiologic literature indicates exposure to two hazards is often worse than the sum of each individual hazard. In other words, during a simultaneous wildfire smoke and heat event, for example, evidence indicates people experience symptoms at lower levels, and/or experience worse symptoms than if they had only been exposed to one hazard alone.20 Guidance on heat co-exposures is particularly important absent federal heat rules and specific training and protections related to heat exposure in many states. Comment:

1. Modify the “Plain Language Summary” to include key exposure control recommendations. However, the section titled “Recommendations and conclusions” could be more useful if it summarized the information in Section 5.2 “Control Recommendations Based Upon Exposure.” A summary could include information on the Air Quality Index (AQI) breakpoints and the following key recommendations:
• Preparation, including a workplace safety and health program.
• Training before the AQI becomes unhealthy for workers.
• Engineering Controls to mitigate exposures, including enclosed structures with filtered air.
• Administrative Controls when engineering controls are not feasible, including relocating or rescheduling work, reducing physical activity, more frequent breaks, and moving duties indoors.

Comment:
4. How can the recommendation in Chapter 4 to use the air quality index (AQI) for PM 2.5 to define exposure control categories be better explained and supported from both a scientific and health communications standpoint? Please provide scientific evidence to support your response as necessary.
Chapter 4’s Community-Based Monitors section provides an in depth description on the various types of monitors or monitoring methods.19 However, the data or results from these monitors are often not reaching outdoor farmworkers who live in areas where they are susceptible to wildland smoke exposure. One of Alianza’s organizers based in Southern California, an area that battles wild fires often, shared that many farmworkers do not receive alerts from employers and learn about air quality news or alerts through their children’s schools. Additionally, the consumer networked particulate matter monitors such as PurpleAir Network are not consistent or reliable for some outdoor farmworkers who do not have reception at their worksites.
Additionally, our partners Lideres Campesinas in Ventura County, California shared about a new pilot program to alert on smoke and wildfire hazards and emergencies, which has reached farmworkers across various worksites in the county. The Ventura County Air Pollution Control District launched the first Farmworker Smoke Alert Text System and recently implemented a pilot program of this system.20 This system sends alerts via text or audio when the AQI reaches unhealthy levels of 151. The system responds to subscribers in both English and Spanish, however, Lideres Campesinas did receive some concerns from farmworkers and community members during the last alert, such as some people not getting the alert on time and continued working through unhealthy AQI levels for hours.
Our partners in Sonoma County, report that outdoor farmworkers use other sources, but these do not specifically measure the AQI. Some farmworkers use SocoAlert and Nixle, but these two require a subscription and registration prior to receiving any alerts.21 Other alert and warning systems that do not require a subscription in advance to receive alerts are Hi-Lo Sirens, Wireless Emergency Alerts (WEA), and Emergency Alert Systems (EAS). Generally, we recommend that any monitoring system, network, or program should keep in mind some challenges to address so that these systems and data are communicated effectively to outdoor farmworkers. Specifically, regarding phone technology, phone accessibility and reception during work, receiving input from the community and workers, as well as acquiring trust in the community to actually subscribe to the application alerts.
Forest workers are in a position similar to farmworkers in that they do not always have immediate access to current information about air quality. This is exacerbated by the fact that they often work in remote areas where they do not have cell phone coverage or internet access.
Even if they can access websites like airnow.gov on their cell phones, the closest air quality monitors to where they are working may be tens of miles, or even over 100 miles, away. At such worksites, the best available option for assessing air quality at any given moment (as winds change and smoke clouds blow in, for example) is probably a hand held device. An added measure to ensure worker awareness of their exposure to wildland fire smoke could be to train forest workers, in a language they understand, in the use of the 5-3-1 Visibility Index.22 This is a way to estimate smoke exposure developed by Oregon’s Department of Environmental Quality. It uses visibility of distant objects, such as mountains, mesas, and other landscape features, to roughly determine the level of pollutants in the air. While such estimates are clearly subjective and not precise, they could help give forest workers a warning as to when they should have their foreman engage the hand-held device, or, if a device is not available, move to another location where the air quality is better.

A barrier to employers implementing recommended methods is implementing linguistically and culturally appropriate and responsive methods, specifically for worker trainings. In this regard, employee trainings should take into account farmworkers’ primary languages, reading levels, and culture. There also should be evaluations of the trainings that will require spaces where workers can share lessons that they have learned. These spaces, moreover, should be clean and adequate for workers to learn from one another and the trainers. Farmworker and forest worker input should also be part of evaluations that could be incorporated into future trainings. Special attention should be paid to training the trainers as well so that they have the required cultural competency, as well as level of expertise. Comment:
One way to address the inadequate training of forest restoration workers is to direct the USDA Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management to require forest restoration contractors to demonstrate and certify at pre-award inspections that their crew members have received adequate training, including safety training, in the knowledge and skills necessary to perform their job duties. Under current agency practice, this is required of vendors seeking wildland firefighting contracts, but it is not required of vendors seeking labor intensive service contracts to do fuels-reduction or pre-commercial thinning, or other types of vegetation management.
Including such a requirement in labor intensive service contracts would help assure that forest restoration workers receive the training that is already required under state and federal law. Federal law as well as the laws of the states of Oregon and Washington require that each employer “shall furnish to each of his employees employment and a place of employment which are free from recognized hazards that are causing or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm to his employees” (29 USC §654.5(a)(1)). Oregon law specifically requires employers or their authorized representative to “provide job safety and health instruction and training to current and new employees, including supervisors, that is adequate for the work task” (OAR 437-007-0140(1)).

Federal service contracts include clauses that require compliance with all applicable labor laws, including those that require training. Requiring contractors to show that they have provided training to their crews at pre-award inspections would help assure compliance with the terms of their contracts as well as with applicable labor laws.

It is well within the Forest Service’s authority to conduct pre-award inspections. Federal Acquisition Regulations state: “The Government has the right to inspect and test all services called for by the contract, to the extent practicable at all times and places during the term of the contract” (FAR 52.246-4(c) (Aug. 1996)).

Current Forest Service practice is to conduct pre-award inspections of wildland firefighting contractor crews and equipment. The contracts wildland firefighting contractors enter into specify the qualifications of the personnel who will work on fire suppression under the contract. Employers are required to have their employees’ training records verified. It is their responsibility to work with a records verification provider to have that verification done. They must present the resulting documentation at the pre-award inspection to demonstrate that their crews meet the training requirements for their respective positions.

In contrast, forest restoration contractors seeking labor intensive service contracts to do pre-commercial or fuels-reduction thinning, pesticide application or other vegetation management are under no such obligations. The nature of the work their crews do—operating chainsaws, felling trees, clearing brush, applying pesticides—is very similar to the work Firefighters 1 and 2 (FFT1 And FFT2) and Incident Sawyers do in fighting wildland fires. Firefighters and forestry services workers also face many of the same workplace hazards: exposure to wildland fire smoke, chainsaw kickback, falling trees and branches, exposure to extreme heat, exposure to dangerous chemicals, to name a few. Despite the similarities between the work and hazards in wildland firefighting and forest restoration, contractors in the forest restoration industry are not required to demonstrate that they have provided their crews with safety and health training adequate to their tasks. Requiring them to do so would help improve employer compliance with safety and health training regulations.

6. Do the recommendations in Chapter 5 adequately address the protection of potentially disadvantaged or at-risk outdoor workers, such as persons with pre-existing health conditions ( e.g., asthma, cardiovascular disease), migrant workers, persons of lower socioeconomic status, and elderly or minor workers? The recommendations in Chapter 5 do not adequately address common health hazards and the protections necessary for at-risk outdoor workers. We agree that it is essential for employers to prepare workers for wildland fire smoke exposure, as stated in Section 5.1.2.1, but believe there are missing considerations in identifying sensitive populations, providing communication methods, and establishing control methods. In terms of one of the listed sensitive populations, outdoor workers, specifically rural farmworkers, are often and consistently exposed to pesticides. This exposure places outdoor farmworkers at an increased risk of developing respiratory, cardiovascular, dementia, and other diseases that render them especially susceptible to the adverse effects of wildland fire smoke.31 We believe exposure to pesticides and herbicides should be listed as an identifier for a “sensitive population.” Including workers exposed to pesticides as a sensitive population is essential, especially for farmworkers, who are at risk of miscarriages, premature delivery, infertility, or developing a fetus with birth defects32 and the combination of pesticide and smoke exposure could heighten the impact of the other. Additionally, there are many farmworkers who experience chronic smoke exposure. Our partner in Florida, the Farmworker Association of Florida, shares that there is a large number of farmworkers in the pine straw harvest industry. These farmworkers do the pine straw harvesting with many of the same problems and conditions as farmworkers everywhere but are exposed to smoke from forest fires for long periods of time. They rake the pine needles in forests and collect them for bundling to be sold for mulch, which is very labor intensive work. Chronic smoke exposure should be a sensitive population category because it is more specific than ‘outdoor workers.’

Outdoor worker housing located in smoke exposure zones or in proximity to smoke is another sensitive population to include. Migrant farmworker housing is typically on or near the fields they work in. These housing accommodations are often substandard, leading to overcrowded housing with poor insulation.33 As a result, migrant farmworker housing is often inadequately equipped to handle smoke infiltration. We recommend that these plans include instruction on how to seek medical care if they experience illness or medical needs due to wildfire smoke and where to seek medical care, keeping in mind that the majority of farmworkers do not have health insurance, many may not speak English, and many would be considered low income or even in poverty. 7. How could the recommendations in Chapter 5 better address accessibility and feasibility for outdoor workers and employers?
We would like to emphasize that farmworkers and forest workers, within the hierarchy of controls, are uniquely exposed to workplace dangers. There is no possibility for eliminating risks, as well as substituting them, as work sites are located outside. Compounding this fact is the reality that many workers are precarious given a lack of legal status, or status as nonimmigrants with easily revoked H-2A or H-2B visas, and poverty. Making accessible PPE and other items that would mitigate the harm of exposure, accordingly, is needed, but difficult to ensure because many workers also lack the power to raise complaints for fear of reprisal.
